image.altText: A smiling woman wearing a yellow top stands in front of a field of yellow flowers

props.synopsis: A mother charged with the attempted murder of her two sons after stabbing them multiple times on an Adelaide motorway has been found not guilty by way of mental incompetence.

title.children: Mother who stabbed her two sons found not guilty by way of mental incompetence

image.altText: A state MP surrounded by journalists outside court.

props.synopsis: Fraud and theft offending by a South Australian MP was fuelled by "greed" and has so far cost him his family home and more than $800,000 in legal fees, a court hears.

title.children: Fraudster MP who stole more than $340k motivated by 'greed', court told

image.altText: A man stands in front of a white wall in american prison

props.synopsis: Former Adelaide megachurch pastor Daniel Menelaou, who was last week charged in the US with possession of child sexual abuse material, has been banned from working with children in SA.

title.children: Pastor arrested in US for alleged abuse banned from working with children

image.altText: Three young children jumping in a puddle on an otherwise dry ground with a tractor in the background

props.synopsis: Many South Australians awoke to the almost unfamiliar sound of rain hitting their roofs as parts of Adelaide experienced falls of 10mm, and the state's west recorded even higher totals.

title.children: Adelaide welcomes wettest weather in more than 100 days amid SA rain

image.altText: A view of the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

props.synopsis: Doctors and nurses say patient care could be compromised if the SA government pushes ahead with plans to shift the infectious diseases unit out of Adelaide’s biggest public hospital and move it to a site across the road.

title.children: Hospital 'Tetris puzzle' could put SA patients at risk, tribunal hears

image.altText: A firefighting volunteer wearing a fedora hat

props.synopsis: Volunteer firefighters and their support staff have travelled more than 1,000 kilometres to help small towns fighting fires in South Australia's south-east.

title.children: Tents, mates, and big breakfasts for travelling volunteers helping firies

image.altText: Trucks and car travelling along a major road

props.synopsis: Community calls for a full duplication of the Sturt Highway have been back by South Australia's peak motoring body, which says planning needs to start now for the project to be realised.

title.children: Business owner's pre-election plea for highway duplication and safety

image.altText: A group of people stand around a man in a suit speaking into a microphone at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Farmers pushed to the brink by drought have joined the state opposition on the steps of Adelaide's Parliament House calling for more government action.

title.children: SA farmers take 'gut-wrenchingly hard' drought battle to parliament

image.altText: An old wooden bridge crossing over a gorge with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: The South Australian Heritage Council has changed the name of a century-old bridge in the Riverland following concerns raised by the public, leaving a local station owner "bewildered".

title.children: Historic bridge renamed over 'negative mental health' concerns

image.altText: A young woman embraces her medical equipment.

props.synopsis: Young South Australian woman Annaliese Holland is terminally ill, but she says being able to plan ahead has given her a sense of empowerment.

title.children: Annaliese likens her life to a 'field of landmines' — but planning has brought her peace

image.altText: Close-up of woman's face looking serious at a playground

props.synopsis: Families and former workers say staffing ratios and profits are jeopardising good care at South Australian childcare centres, as data shows serious incidents are on the rise.

title.children: Child found sleeping in the sun at childcare, grandmother says

image.altText: A young man in a white polo shirt smiles in a radio studio

props.synopsis: Adelaide United defender Josh Cavallo, Australia's first openly gay professional footballer, says he still receives daily death threats since coming out more than three years ago.

title.children: A-League player reveals daily death threats since coming out as gay

image.altText: Paul Tilbury is wearing a suit but no tie

props.synopsis: Over two years, disability support provider Paul Kevan Tilbury falsely claimed more than $400,000 from the NDIS and used the cash to buy meals, jewellery, alcohol, tobacco and to install a home bar.

title.children: 'Shameful' NDIS provider jailed for fraudulently claiming $400,000

image.altText: An orange wave buoy rider in the ocean, words keep clean visible.

props.synopsis: It's been seven months since the Cape du Couedic wave buoy started malfunctioning off Kangaroo Island, with the BOM blaming supply issues in Canada for delays to a replacement.

title.children: No fix in sight for broken Bureau of Meteorology wave buoy

image.altText: A view of the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: Administrators of the Whyalla steelworks say they do not have enough funding to keep it running for 12 months, with the troubled industrial plant set to endure another blast furnace shutdown.

title.children: Whyalla steelworks in 'state of disrepair' as blast furnace faces new shutdown

image.altText: A man wearing a khaki fleece is handcuffed behind his back. A man in a blue tee holds his arm

props.synopsis: The Trump administration has drawn pushback for attempting to deport a permanent resident under an obscure and untested Cold War-era statute. Here's what to know.

title.children: Whisked away and facing deportation, this man could become a thorn in Trump's side

image.altText: A man dressed for freezing conditions hauls a sled across an icy landscape.

props.synopsis: Aaron Crook estimates he got 11 hours sleep in seven days as he trekked 620 kilometres across the Arctic Circle to win one of the world's toughest races.

title.children: SA man endures frostnip, hallucinations to win Arctic ultra-marathon

image.altText: Dutton, standing at a lectern, looks towards a disturbance in the crowd.

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is repeatedly interrupted by protesters as he outlines the Coalition's foreign principles to the Lowy Institute.

title.children: Anti-nuclear protesters accuse Dutton of lying to Australians — as it happened

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market gained strongly on hopes for two more US rate cuts this year, and as weaker jobs numbers kept a May rate cut as the next likely move for the RBA.

title.children: ASX gains, as employment drops and May rate cut remains likely — as it happened

image.altText: A small bowl of plain elbow pasta next to a red squeeze bottle.

props.synopsis: Parents say they are being lied to about the quality of food at childcare centres across the country. Some say they were promised in-house chefs but children were served "two-minute noodles".

title.children: 'We don't actually serve that': Parents lied to about childcare food standards

image.altText: SpaceX dragon capsule entering the earth's atmosphere

props.synopsis: After 268 days without fresh air or a proper shower, Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams made their final journey back to Earth.

title.children: Falling from the stars and greeted by dolphins: How NASA's 'stranded' astronauts came home

image.altText: A screenshot of a video posted to RedNote shows Peter Dutton and the words "Dutton will not use Aboriginal flag".

props.synopsis: A series of attacks on Australian political parties on emerging Chinese social media platform RedNote raise concerns about misinformation, disinformation and the risk of foreign interference ahead of the federal election.

title.children: A deepfake Dutton speaks Mandarin on Chinese social media platform

image.altText: A graphic showing a range of reader comments about potential issues in Australia's 2025 federal election.

props.synopsis: What do you need to know as we head into a budget, just weeks out from a federal election? Have Your Say.

title.children: Have Your Say: What matters to you in this year's pre-election budget?

image.altText: Chimneys from Scarborough's Pluto gas facility with flames coming from them.

props.synopsis: Gas consumption in Australia is falling faster than anticipated, helping to avoid the risks of seasonal shortages in the next few years, according to energy commentators.

title.children: Looming gas crisis averted as Australian use plummets

image.altText: A photo of Sol overlaid on a photo of a two bathroom stalls - one for women and one for men.

props.synopsis: With universities and sports stadiums installing gender-inclusive bathrooms, Australia is considering making changes to make it easier to do so. We unpack what the proposed changes would mean.

title.children: Australia considering making changes to build all-gender bathrooms

image.altText: A young boy in Adolescence looks menacing in an extreme close-up.

props.synopsis: Netflix's new one-take crime drama takes toxic masculinity to a violent extreme. We asked an expert to help us unpack how reflective Adolescence is of our real world.

title.children: 'You must trick them': How the online world shapes teen misogyny

image.altText: Jenny Hutson March 20 2025

props.synopsis: The corporate watchdog's case against the former chairwoman of Australia's biggest share market-listed childcare operator has collapsed.

title.children: Childcare giant's former chair Jenny Hutson has criminal charges dropped

image.altText: A dog is silhouetted running alongside a side-by-side in a picturesque landscape with green trees and rolling hills.

props.synopsis: Newly released safety statistics show side-by-side vehicles were involved in 14 deaths on Australian farms in 2024 despite being fitted with seatbelts and rollover protection cages.

title.children: Vehicle touted as safer than quad bikes now leading killer on farms

image.altText: Gathering against the CIGEO nuclear waste project in Toulouse 2018

props.synopsis: A series of massive underground tunnels for nuclear waste are under construction across Europe and the UK, but how we will warn future generations of their dangers is still up in the air.

title.children: Nuclear waste remains dangerous for 4.5 billion years. So what do we do with it?

image.altText: A laptop showing the homepage of ChatGPT.

props.synopsis: OpenAI says its latest chatbot should make fewer "hallucination" errors based on a measurement system the company devised. So how does it work, and what does it show?

title.children: 'Flawed from the start': Accuracy of OpenAI's newest GPT questioned

image.altText: Four women, wearing white t-shirts underneath blue Great Britain singlets hold oars while rowing.

props.synopsis: Throughout her career, Olympic rower Caragh McMurtry faced challenges she now understands as characteristic of her autism. But she says being neurodivergent was critical to her sporting success.

title.children: Neurodivergent athletes may be over-represented in elite sport. Here's why

image.altText: Woman with dark hair smiles into the camera

props.synopsis: Reducing the time people spend job hunting has a broader economic benefit, with a report finding one charity helping women into the workforce has generated $86 million in net direct economic benefits over the past 20 years.

title.children: Mariana's 'Cinderella' story is repeated thousands of times and the benefits are in the millions

image.altText: A man in a courtyard resting his arms on a broom

props.synopsis: The Real Estate Institute of Australia says tenants are under no legal obligation to hire a professional to tidy their rental garden or courtyard.

title.children: How tidy does your garden need to be at the end of a lease?

image.altText: Former Wollongong Mayor and State MP Frank Arkell

props.synopsis: A new biography of the former lord mayor of Wollongong, Frank Arkell, reveals evidence suggesting police were aware of his involvement with a paedophile ring more than a decade before he was charged with child sex offences.

title.children: 'Mr Wollongong' child sex links known to police, biographer says

image.altText: A teenage boy holding a plank of wood like a rifle in his kitchen while wearing a yellow bucket hat.

props.synopsis: The court heard that Nicholas Prosper had withdrawn into an online world and illegally bought a firearm as he plotted to carry out an attack on a primary school north of London.

title.children: British teen who murdered mother, brother and sister jailed for 49 years
